Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Quantifying the footprint of a dominant organism: Biogeochemical impacts of leaf cutter ants in a lowland tropical forest ecosystem
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will provide information on the contribution of an ecologically important ant guild to the carbon cycle and will help improve predictions of future carbon dynamics in tropical forests. One of the most conspicuous features of a tropical forest is the abundance of leaf cutter ants. Despite their prominence, little is known about the overall contribution of leaf cutter ants to carbon and nutrient cycles in tropical ecosystems. These tropical and subtropical forested ecosystems cover 17% of the Earth's land mass and store approximately 40% of all carbon and are an important determinant of the global carbon cycle. Leaf cutters are the dominant herbivores in tropical forest ecosystems, bringing 10-50 % of all surrounding vegetation into the nest, fertilizing nest soils, and promoting the release of carbon dioxide and methane into the atmosphere. The network of leafcutter ant trails extend throughout the forest and workers walk single-file, carrying pieces of leaves into their nests, where special fungi break down the plant material and produce hyphae, on which the ants feed. Leaf cutter ant nests are massive in size and during nest construction and maintenance ants mix leaf particles into the soil and alter soil chemistry. Leaf cutter ant activities have the possibility of controlling aspects of ecosystem dynamics, though the degree of their influence has not been quantified.

The project will focus on the role of leafcutter ant nests as hotspots of carbon dioxide and methane emissions and the role of nests in altering soil chemistry and creating heterogeneity in carbon (C), nitrogen (N), and phosphorus (P) in the soil across the landscape. The work will be conducted at La Selva Biological Research Station, Costa Rica, which is an epicenter of tropical scientific research, hosting a large number of student groups, researchers from all over the world. The project will characterize C dynamics on leafcutter ant nests and differentiate the sources of carbon dioxide and methane emissions between the activities of ants, fungi, the nest microbial community, and roots and hyphae. The N, and P biogeochemistry of active leafcutter ant nests will be quantified as well as the soil legacy effects after nests are abandoned. The project uses a multi-faceted approach, including coupling continuous measurements of soil carbon dioxide emissions with discrete measures of methane efflux, stable C isotopes of carbon dioxide to determine sources, soil C and N pools and fluxes, estimates of root and fungal biomass, and microbial community and functional indices. Measurements will be performed on ant nests, paired non-nest sites, and along a sequence of nests abandoned at different times in the past to quantify how long the impact of altered biogeochemistry persists in areas occupied by nests. These biogeochemical fluxes will be incorporated into an ecosystem model to estimate C flux at local-to-regional scales. The project will strengthen international collaborations by working with researchers and students from the US, Costa Rica, and New Zealand. In addition to training a postdoctoral researcher and mentoring several REU students, project scientists will conduct an annual workshop to introduce students and researchers to cutting edge field instrumentation and analysis techniques and provide opportunities to use these new approaches at La Selva. La Selva Biological Research Station is an epicenter of tropical scientific research, hosting a large number of student groups, researchers from all over the world, and serving as a center for ecotourism, thus the proposed research will be widely disseminated.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit. We have determined that LCA nests maintain lower soil CO2 (relative to control soils) levels because they fundamentally change soil structure and gas flow dynamics through nest soils. The latter appears to be the result of more efficient soil gas diffusion due to LCA-reduced soil tortuosity. The differences between nests and controls are seasonal, more pronounced during the wet season, when precipitation blocks gas transport in control soils. The loss rates are also climatic. During the El Nino drought, control soils respired more C, including more heterotrophic C than nests. During the wet La Nina, nest soils respired more C, largely through vents, than control soils.

Belowground production was calculated using averages of hyphae and root standing crop biomass and lifespans. Shorter hyphal and root lifespans and increased turnover indicate that there is greater belowground productivity in nests than the control. Hyphal production in the control and nests was 226.69 g C m?2 yr-1 and 723.48 g C m-2 yr-1, respectively. Root production was also higher in nests than the control at 1229.70 g C m?2 yr-1 and 234.59 g C m?2 yr-1, respectively.

To provide nest-scale CO2 emissions estimates relative to non-nest soil zones, we integrated our soil and vent emissions observations using estimates of nest area, vent numbers and vent opening size from our field observations. A reasonable range of soil CO2 efflux values in this forest is 4 to 7 kg m-2 yr-1, and nest surface area ranges from 30 to 70 m2. The soil ground surface of a nest emits 120 to 490 kg CO2 annually. For vent efflux, based on an observed average vent efflux value of 2.1 104 kg CO2 m-2 yr-1, an average of 32 vents per mature nest, and average vent opening (0.00021 m2), the total vent CO2 emissions is about 72 kg CO2 yr-1. These values suggest that an average Atta cephalotes nest area emits around 0.2 to 0.6 t CO2 per nest and year, i.e., 15% to 60% more than an equivalent area of soil in a lowland tropical forest. 1.2% of the La Selva surface of primary and secondary forest was occupied by Atta cephalotes nests. Given our estimate that nest soils emit around 15% to 60% more than non-nest soils, we estimated that Atta cephalotes nests in Neotropical rainforest respire from 0.2% to 0.7% more C than control soils, effectively more than doubling the C processing.

Also important is how soil C dynamics respond to events. A complete ENSO cycle (El Niño drought, and La Niña heavy rainfall), and a hurricane occurred during our study period. Control and nest soil responded differently, in CO2 production, growth and mortality, and nutrient dynamics. All of these are currently being integrated into a comprehensive whole response of this ecosystem.

 

Broader Impacts.

We had two primary broader impact objectives: understanding the importance of leaf-cutter ants in tropical rainforests and how those affect our global environment, and providing training for students in cultural interactions as well as ecological research.

We found that leaf-cutter ants only occupy a small fraction (1-2%) of the land area, but may be processing as much or more C than the surrounding soil. This occurs both directly, through leaf harvest and transport to feed their gardens, but also indirectly in two ways.  First, by designing a structure with vents that drain CO2 from surrounding soil pipes surrounding roots and fungal hyphal networks, and second by increasing O2 locally and refuse piles rich in nutrients that attracts root and fungal hyphal growth, and a compliment of soil invertebrates that dramatically increases carbon turnover. Thus, leaf cutter ants are critical elements sustaining a tropical rainforest, itself crucial to global carbon budgets.

Second, we provided a rich environment and interaction opportunities between students and postdocs in the US and Latin America. We ran workshops for undergraduates stimulating interacting projects between Latin American and US students. We also provided for a number of undergraduate opportunities both to work in a tropical rainforest, and to work with complex ecosystem data in US laboratories. We also provided advanced training for graduate students and postgraduate researchers in the US, and for graduate students in Costa Rica, including exchanges, and the experience to work with data ranging from sequencing to ecosystem carbon budgets.
